awd_titl_txt: RUI: The Function and Regulation of Invertase Inhibitors during Early Seed Development in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration:
Seed is a major renewable resource for the production of food, feed, energy, and industrial materials. Proper seed development relies on the nutrients imported from the maternal plant, as well as appropriate nutrient allocation among the three seed compartments, the embryo, the endosperm, and the seed coat. Very little is known about how nutrient allocation is regulated at the interface between the endosperm and the embryo. This project will investigate how two genes expressed in the endosperm influence the rate of sugar transport to the embryo. The outcome of the project will advance our knowledge on the genetic mechanisms that control seed size, which will be applicable to the improvement of yield and grain quality in crop species. This project will enhance research capacity and improve undergraduate STEM education through the integration of research and teaching at a women's liberal arts college for African Americans. Undergraduate students will be recruited to conduct independent research in the PI's lab. The project is expected to improve the recruitment of minority and women students into STEM disciplines. 

It is well known that the timing of endosperm cellularization affects embryo growth rate. However, the underlying molecular mechanism has remained largely unexplored. This project will test the hypothesis that the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) represses the expression of invertase inhibitor (InvINHs) genes to regulate sugar allocation between the endosperm and the embryo. The specific aims are to establish the causality between InvINHs and the suppression of embryo growth through genetic manipulation, and to identify the cis-elements and the transcription factors that regulate InvINHs expression. The proposed activity is expected to establish how a master regulator of endosperm cellularization, the PRC2 complex, regulates nutrient allocation between the embryo and the endosperm via the repression of InvINHs. A deeper understanding of this connection will allow us to further investigate how modifications in the endosperm developmental program have shaped the evolution of seed morphology.

por.por_cntn:
Seeds are packed with nutrients to support seedling growth. These nutrients also make up a significant portion of human diet and animal feed. Understanding seed growth and development has been an active area of research, which has the potential to lead to positive economic impact. While we have accumulated a great body of knowledge on seed development, it is still not clear what determines nutrient partition between the embryo and the endosperm.

In this project, we identified an invertase inhibitor (InvINH1) in a model organism, Arabidopsis. Our data indicated that InvINH1 is specifically expressed in the endosperm to suppress embryo growth during the early stage of seed development. Later on, InvINH1 expression is down-regulated, which coincides with accelerated embryo growth. We also discovered that several AGL transcription factors form dimers that bind a region of the InvINH1 promoter to activate InvINH1 expression. During the late stage of seed development, these AGLs are downregulated by the PRC2 chromatin remodeling complex. The PRC2 complex is known to regulate the developmental transition called endosperm cellularization. Therefore, our data provided the missing link between this seed developmental transition and the shift in nutrient supply from the endosperm to the embryo. 

This project was carried out at a liberal arts college for African American women. During the funding period, 20-30 undergraduate students had conducted independent research either as summer research fellows, research assistants during the semester, or as students enrolled in the PI’s research course. Collectively, these students made 15 presentations at professional conferences, while six students earned co-authorship on two publications that are the products of this project. Many of these students have moved on to graduate schools or medical schools. In addition to providing research opportunities to undergraduate students, this project also provided opportunities to a postdoctoral fellow to teach and mentor undergraduate students. This postdoctoral fellow is now an Assistant Professor at another university.

This project also supported various K12 outreach activities. The PI and the undergraduate students had participated every year as the exhibitor at Atlanta Science Festival Expo until the event was disrupted by the pandemic in 2020. During the pandemic, the PI carried out virtual classroom visits at three local elementary schools, which serve mostly minority students. Collectively, these activities have engaged hundreds of children in STEM-related activities.
